content:
Imagine you are a robot browsing the web, just like humans. Now you need to complete a task. In each iteration, you will receive an Observation that includes a screenshot of a webpage and some texts. This screenshot will feature Numerical Labels placed in the TOP LEFT corner of each Web Element.
Carefully analyze the visual information to identify the Numerical Label corresponding to the Web Element that requires interaction, then follow the guidelines and choose one of the following actions:
1. Click a Web Element.
2. Delete existing content in a textbox and then type content. 
3. Scroll up or down. Multiple scrolls are allowed to browse the webpage. Pay attention!! The default scroll is the whole window. If the scroll widget is located in a certain area of the webpage, then you have to specify a Web Element in that area. I would hover the mouse there and then scroll.
4. Wait. Typically used to wait for unfinished webpage processes, with a duration of 5 seconds.
5. Go back, returning to the previous webpage.
6. Google, directly jump to the Google search page. When you can't find information in some websites, try starting over with Google.
7. Answer. This action should only be chosen when all questions in the task have been solved.

Correspondingly, Action should STRICTLY follow the format:
- Click [Numerical_Label]
- Type [Numerical_Label]; [Content]
- Scroll [Numerical_Label or WINDOW]; [up or down]
- Wait
- GoBack
- Google
- ANSWER; [content]

Key Guidelines You MUST follow:
* Action guidelines *
1) To input text, NO need to click textbox first, directly type content. After typing, the system automatically hits `ENTER` key. Sometimes you should click the search button to apply search filters. Try to use simple language when searching.  
2) You must Distinguish between textbox and search button, don't type content into the button! If no textbox is found, you may need to click the search button first before the textbox is displayed. 
3) Execute only one action per iteration. 
4) STRICTLY Avoid repeating the same action if the webpage remains unchanged. You may have selected the wrong web element or numerical label. Continuous use of the Wait is also NOT allowed.
5) When a complex Task involves multiple questions or steps, select "ANSWER" only at the very end, after addressing all of these questions (steps). Flexibly combine your own abilities with the information in the web page. Double check the formatting requirements in the task when ANSWER. 
* Web Browsing Guidelines *
1) Don't interact with useless web elements like Login, Sign-in, donation that appear in Webpages. Pay attention to Key Web Elements like search textbox and menu.
2) Vsit video websites like YouTube is allowed BUT you can't play videos. Clicking to download PDF is allowed and will be analyzed by the Assistant API.
3) Focus on the numerical labels in the TOP LEFT corner of each rectangle (element). Ensure you don't mix them up with other numbers (e.g. Calendar) on the page.
4) Focus on the date in task, you must look for results that match the date. It may be necessary to find the correct year, month and day at calendar.
5) Pay attention to the filter and sort functions on the page, which, combined with scroll, can help you solve conditions like 'highest', 'cheapest', 'lowest', 'earliest', etc. Try your best to find the answer that best fits the task.

Your reply should strictly follow the format:
Thought: {Your brief thoughts (briefly summarize the info that will help ANSWER)}
Action: {One Action format you choose}
Confidence: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating your confidence level in the action. A higher value means greater confidence.}
Completion: {A float between 0 and 1 indicating how much of the task has been completed until now. Zero means no progress has been made and one means full completion.}

Then the User will provide:
Observation: {A labeled screenshot Given by User}
Now given a task: Find a Mexico hotel with deals for December 25-26.  Please interact with https://www.booking.com/ and get the answer.Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: To find a hotel in Mexico, I should start by entering "Mexico" as the destination in the "Where are you going?" textbox.
Action: Type [14]; Mexico
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.15
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The system is currently set to Niagara Falls with the calendar open, but we need hotel deals in Mexico for December 25-26. The calendar is currently displaying September and October 2025; I need to navigate to December. Clicking "Next month" should move the calendar closer to December.
Action: Click [18]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.2
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar now displays October and November 2025. To select December 25-26, I need to continue moving forward to reach December 2025. Clicking "Next month" again should bring December into view.
Action: Click [19]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.22
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The calendar now displays December 2025. I can now select December 25 (check-in, [87]) and December 26 (check-out, [88]). To select both, I should start by clicking December 25.
Action: Click [87]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.35
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: December 25 has been selected as the check-in date. Now I need to select December 26 (the next day) as the check-out date to match the user's requirement.
Action: Click [88]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.45
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The dates are now set to December 25–26, but the destination is still Niagara Falls. I need to search for hotels in Mexico. I should enter "Mexico" in the destination textbox.
Action: Type [13]; Mexico
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.55
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The destination textbox [13] still shows "Niagara Falls" instead of "Mexico" even after entering "Mexico". I need to click the Search button to update the results for Mexico with the selected dates.
Action: Click [17]
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.7
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The destination is still Niagara Falls and not Mexico, so the search did not update. It appears I have to clear or overwrite the destination in the textbox [13] so that it only contains "Mexico", and then click Search again.
Action: Type [13]; Mexico
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.75
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The destination textbox [13] still shows "Niagara Falls". I previously tried typing "Mexico", but the page did not update. I need to clear the textbox and then re-enter "Mexico", or initiate the destination change by clicking in the textbox to activate it and trigger possible location suggestions.
Action: Click [13]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.8
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The destination textbox [13] is now active for typing. To change the search to Mexico, I need to remove "Niagara Falls" and type "Mexico" in the textbox.
Action: Type [13]; Mexico
Confidence: 1.0
Completion: 0.85
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The textbox content still only shows "Niagara Falls"—it doesn't show "Mexico" yet, indicating that the location hasn't been confirmed or the suggestion list hasn't been selected. Usually, after typing, clicking the Search button will update the results to the new destination and dates.
Action: Click [17]
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.9
Observation: A screenshot and some texts. (Omitted in context.)

Thought: The page still shows results for Niagara Falls and not Mexico. The textbox [13] does not reflect the destination change, meaning the search action did not register the new location. There may be a need to select "Mexico" from a dropdown that usually appears after typing, or the destination input interaction needs further completion, such as hitting Enter after typing "Mexico".
Action: Type [13]; Mexico
Confidence: 0.95
Completion: 0.92

content:
Thought: Typing "Mexico" is not updating the destination from "Niagara Falls". The interface may require selecting "Mexico" from a dropdown suggestion list after typing it. To trigger this suggestion, I should click the blank button [14] next to the destination input, which likely displays location suggestions.
Action: Click [14]
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.93

Thought: After typing "Mexico," the destination in the textbox still shows "Niagara Falls," and the page displays Niagara Falls hotel results. This suggests the destination must be selected from suggestions, not just typed. I need to trigger the suggestion dropdown again, possibly by refocusing the textbox and then looking for a relevant suggestion to click (such as "Mexico").
Action: Click [13]
Confidence: 0.9
Completion: 0.95
